title: Monday, 7th November, 2016
bodyHTML:

PM

PM

So a bit zonked

PM

But this is a big week

PM

And the end of the FBI email probe

Well, it's always going to look calm against that Brexit spike in June.

BE

In any normal year, the run into November would be removing the enamel from your teeth. But this is no normal year.

PM

Here's some UBS, in passing

11:12 am
PM

The US presidential election is the key event in the week ahead. How will it impact FX and rates markets?

PM

Well, here's the summary

PM

I will try and put a usual place pack together later

11:12 am
PM

Near term, the US electoral outcome is unlikely to change macro trends
It is difficult to translate electoral platforms into implemented legislation and thus we are cautious in extrapolating to FX and rates markets. Moreover, despite expected associations, analysing the market impact of the US elections is not equivalent to the recent UK Referendum.

The likely 'first best' is to look for trading opportunities after the election
In the aftermath of the global financial crisis, a new cyclical normal has emerged for asset markets; the occasions of unpredictable noisy episodes with unpredictable duration has increased, however, the first best is to trade them ex post.

In a 'second best' environment, the options are limited and possibly exotic
A win by Hillary Clinton is largely priced by markets, and shouldn't have a large medium-term impact on FX or rates markets or our core views. A win by Donald Trump is less expected by markets, and would likely therefore have a larger market impact. For investors looking to trade a Trump win in FX, correlations suggest that USD/MXN is the place to express this view; however, it is still difficult to trade it with good risk-reward. The FX alternative is likely USD-Asia.

Equities do not offer ex-ante solutions, but plenty of opportunities ex-post
Our equity strategists and analysts have published a few reports that should guide investment choices on a conditional basis to the electoral results in sectors amenable to such opportunities. Please see below a list of our related research.

PM

And want a free Lex?

BE

I guess so.

11:13 am
PM

US election: country (risk) first

PM

Does the world demand at least a single, safe haven market? Since the financial crisis, that island of stability has been the US. Predictable (if gridlocked) politics, steady economic growth, the world’s reserve currency and a solidifying banking sector have made it stand out. Even the occasional crisis over the debt ceiling failed to dent the rise of US government bonds.

But this singular status is fragile. As Donald Trump’s chances of becoming president have rallied in recent days, anxiety has rattled US financial markets. The S&P 500 index has declined for nine consecutive trading days (though overall it is down just 3 per cent). Junk bond spreads have widened again. The Vix option volatility index has risen from 16 to nearly 23.

PM

There had previously been narrow, specific trades to make tied to the contest: sell the Mexican peso on Mr Trump’s antitrade stance, or turn bearish on healthcare stocks because of Hillary Clinton’s rhetoric on prescription drug prices. But a broader reset may be forthcoming if the relative sobriety of American politics is about to be lost.

That Tuesday’s election has been become a referendum on change is in itself remarkable. Last Friday, the Department of Labor reported that the unemployment rate had dipped below 5 per cent, less than half where it stood early in 2010. US annualised GDP growth in the most recent quarter was 2.9 per cent. With wages and inflation rising, the probability of the Federal Reserve raising interest rates in December remains above 70 per cent. In anticipation, the 10-year Treasury yield had inched up to above 1.8 per cent from 1.5 per cent over the summer. Presidential histrionics aside, it is already a tricky time for monetary policymakers.

11:13 am
PM

Perhaps oddly, though, 10-year Treasury yields have eased back slightly in recent days as Mr Trump has gained in the opinion polls. This is a candidate who has questioned the independence of Fed chair Janet Yellen, mused on the benefits of sovereign default and espoused trade barriers that would likely be inflationary. Collectively, it is difficult to imagine how these positions could favour medium-term US debt.

It may be that whoever prevails in the election, the dizzying run of stocks and high-yield bonds through the Obama years must inevitably cool. Still, while the placid Treasury market may be surprising, the rising flow into short-term money funds and a jump in the gold price shows that — for the first time in a long time — the US is exhibiting country risk too.

PM

Done

BE

Oh, and if you want to drive yourself to distraction over the next 24 hours I suggest bookmarking the Befair "next President" exchange market.

11:19 am
BE

So anyway, here's UBS to take us through the headlines.

BE

HSBC reported adj. 3Q16 profit of US$5,591m, 10% ahead of consensus and 11% higher than UBSe. Further adjusting for US$100m in life manufacturing gains (a US$300m YoY swing) and perhaps US$100m of the US$180m QoQ increase in Legacy Credit revenues in GB&M, adj. PBT of US$5,391m was a 6% beat to consensus. Within this income was 3% or US$330m light, costs 4% or US$302m better and impairments the real driver of the beat, 38% / US$347m better. In line with other banks to have reported, GBM was a key driver of the beat, with income 12% ahead of UBSe, seeing GBM deliver 80% of the operating division beat compared to our forecast.

BE

The key feature of the numbers is the reported CT1 of 13.9% and leverage ratio of 5.4%, substantially ahead of expectations and management's target. Even excluding the uplift to CT1 from a change to the regulator's treatment of HSBC's Bank of Communications stake – worth 1% of CT1 – capital was a beat. At 2Q16 results HSBC management announced a buyback sufficient to take CT1 back to ~12.5% on a pro-forma basis (including the sale of Brazil to Bradesco), the mid-point of HSBC's 12-13% target ratio. At today's print HSBC has excess capital of US$13bn, 9% of market cap. Though only 40% of the current US$2.5bn buyback is complete, the full impact of that is already reflected in regulatory capital. On the 2Q16 conference call management appeared confident of a US-driven buyback for 2017: they will be hard-pressed to end today's call without adding a payout from the BoComm capital backing too, we think.

11:20 am
BE

HSBC is trading at 1.0x TNAV for a forecast ROTE of 9% in 2017, 11.1x EPS. A gross running yield of 6.9% falls to 5.2% assuming 25% scrip take-up.

BE

And Citi, fresh off the conference call.

BE

Capital Return Potential - The HSBC CFO noted that "going from 12.1% to 13.9% CET1 is of course a positive", while the bank also has very strong capital ratios in the majority of the group's subsidiaries. The CEO indicated that this gives the company additional flexibility for capital return: "This is another action forming part of our ongoing capital management of the group that reinforces our ability to support the dividend, to invest in the business and, over the medium term, to contemplate share buy-backs, as appropriate." We see a secure ongoing 7% dividend yield. Capital Requirements - Following the PRA's annual review HSBC's Pillar 2A requirement has increased by 30bps. As a result the company are now guiding to a CET1 requirement at the upper-end of the previous 12.0-13.0% range, with the CFO confirming that 12.5%-13.0% is the "absolutely right place to be" in the medium-term. Relative to the current 13.9% CET1 ratio this implies a capital surplus at Group level of c$8-13bn, albeit capital ratios are likely to dip slightly in the fourth quarter due to the bank levy, 4Q dividend accrual and usual seasonal factors.

11:21 am
BE

Is The Surplus Capital Distributable? - The 1ppt CET1 ratio positive from the regulatory deconsolidation of BoCom relates to a change in capital treatment at the Group (HoldCo) level. In contrast it does not impact on the HSBC AP subsidiary, as the HKMA already allowed the capital deduction method for BoCom. Consequently it would appear that the accounting change today does not directly lead to higher distributable income from the HK subsidiary. Nonetheless HSBC management highlighted that the bank has strong capital ratios in all its Asian entities and indicated that any capital surplus at the subsidiary level would be distributed back to the Group on a "timely basis". In turn the Group CET1 ratio is expected to revert back to c12.5-13.0%, following excess capital return, in the "medium-term".

BE

RBWM Outlook - On a constant FX basis, HSBC is making "slow progress". UK mortgage lending is growing, with 10 broker channels now in operation and another 13 broker channels under review. The full impact on volumes from the intermediary channel is yet to be seen, but HSBC is already taking share in UK mortgages (8.4% YTD vs 7.2% last year). There is some loan margin pressure in HK, but this is offset by lower funding cost. A pick up in Asia equity markets also helped 3Q16 retail & wealth management, especially in HK and Mainland China. Mexico is recovering. CMB Outlook - Commercial Bank loan growth is strong. Trade balances have been stable the past two quarters as HSBC has gained share in a shrinking market. Trade NIM has held up well globally as client have switched from plain vanilla to structured products. Payment and Cash management NIM is now improving.

BE

Buy Rating - HSBC shares have a 7% dividend yield. With the CET1 buffer growing, this can realistically now be viewed as a net yield going forward without the offset of a regular dilution from scrip issuance. HSBC shares are trading at a PE of c11x 2017E and c10x 2018E. We have a Buy rating, target price 665p.

A $1.0bn Attributable Loss in Q3 2016 (ex PVIF), or 3c per share, compares unfavourably to a profit of £4.7bn in Q3 2015. tNAV per share fell by 16c (2%) QoQ to $7.37, leaving the stock trading on 1.0x. Customer loans declined by $7bn (3% annualised) with an L/D ratio of 68% and NIM fell to a new (unquantified) low. However, “Adjusted” PBT of $5.6bn was $0.5bn (10/11%) ahead of company-compiled consensus/Investec forecasts, primarily reflecting sharply lower impairments of $0.6bn vs $1.6bn in Q3 2015. SELL.

BE

By Benjamin Katz and David Hellier
(Bloomberg) -- EasyJet Plc directors are in early-stage
talks about relaxing executive bonus targets in order to hang on
to Chief Executive Officer Carolyn McCall and other top managers
as a capacity glut and the Brexit vote put the U.K. carrier’s
earnings under pressure, people familiar with the plans said.
The EasyJet board wants to make pay goals more achievable
amid concerns that McCall and her team may be lured to other
companies as aviation bears the brunt of economic and political
uncertainty, according to the people, who asked not to be named
as the proposals haven’t been made public.

11:44 am
BE

With its H1 results, Ryanair has announced a further share
buyback programme of up to €550m over the four-month
period from November 2016 to February 2017 (this results in
greater than €1bn for FY 2017 and almost €4.8bn in total). In addition, the
longer-term traffic growth forecast has been raised by over
10% from 180m to over 200m customers a year by FY 2024. The
airline has also raised its medium-term guidance for ancillary
sales from 20% to 30% of revenues over the next four years to
FY 2020. H1 profit after tax, at €1,168m, was modestly ahead of
consensus at €1,150m and Davy at €1,147m, driven by a strong
Q2 cost performance. Recently revised FY 2017 net income
guidance of €1.3-1.35bn has been maintained. We are likely to
retain our FY 2017 forecast of €1.325bn but will up our FY 2018
forecast (currently €1.385bn) by c.5%, factoring in better cost
performance and strong traffic momentum. We maintain our
‘Outperform’ rating and €16 price target.

BE

And some RBC.

BE

OUR VIEW - H2 average fares down more than 20% or a further 10-11% 2017/18E
decline (RBCe down 7-8%) priced in to reach 10-year median 13.2x PER.
In short, this implies either upside left on the shares, or investors price
in further decline in 2017/18E (even as industry fuel costs are rising into
winter 2017/18). We see a 20% H2 fare drop as very unlikely (the company
only ever came close to this in 2003/04 when it grew seat supply by 54%
YoY).
Longer term we note that: (1) Ryanair is ruthless at reallocating
underperforming capacity - and has the scope to do so across 85 European
bases (if the UK were to worsen) - unlike some UK peers whose operating
capital is likely trapped in the UK; (2) If pricing weakness persists and
compounds, combined with rising spot fuel prices, then we would expect
to eventually see planned or unplanned competitor capacity exits. (We
see lowest cost providers as most likely to win the competition for the
vacuum this could create).

BE

Fever-Tree continues to make strong progress in the UK and, despite tougher
2H comparatives, looks set to deliver another sparkling performance in
FY16E. This results in an increase in our revenue assumptions of 11% for the
FY (to now show c59% growth) and an adjusted PBT forecast upgrade of 17%.
We leave our forward growth rate assumptions unchanged, but forecasts
increase from the higher FY16E base. Our TP (DCF-based) increases to 1140p
and we continue to rate the stock a BUY.

12:00 pm
BE

 Fever-Tree has issued a trading update indicating that revenue has continued
to build at a healthy rate in 2H. As a result, FY16 profits are expected to be
materially ahead of current market expectations.
 We had been forecasting 43% revenue growth for the full year after the group
had delivered 69% in 1H, which implied 26% in 2H. We increase this 2H
assumption to 51.6% and as a result our full year projection increases to 58.5%,
which takes the absolute number to £93.9m, an 11% uplift.
 The main contribution to this increase is stronger than expected growth in the UK,
with both on- and off-trade contributing. There was no one significant factor, but
distribution gains have continued, accompanied by a good rate of sales progress.
We modestly increase assumptions for Europe and the USA, where further
weakness in sterling since July has also added a little to revenues.
 Whilst currency will help the gross profit margin a little more in 2H (in 1H FX
added 1.5pps to GM%), there will be some offset from geographic mix, with the
UK the main factor in this upgrade. Hence, we leave our GM% assumption at
55%. We do expect to see some operational gearing at the EBIT line, with
operating expenses not increasing in line with revenues, as towards the end of
the year much of the marketing budget has been spent/committed.
 We lift FY16E adjusted PBT from £26.5m to £30.9m (+17%). EPS are 21.3p
(prev 18.3p). For FY17E, we make no changes to our growth rate assumptions,
but, with a higher base revenue, this results in an upgrade to adjusted PBT to
£32.5m with EPS of 22.4p (prev £28.8m, 19.8p).

BE

And Shore.

BE

Fever-Tree has issued a brief trading update ahead of its year ended December 2016 in which it states that the company has continued to perform strongly in the second half of the year. The UK, which is the group’s largest market, has been particularly strong due to the benefit of new distribution gains combined with a continued strong rate of sale growth. As a result, the Board now expects results for the year to be materially ahead of market expectations. We are currently forecasting CPBT of £27.4m (EPS of 19.4p) which we will be upgrading in due course post speaking to management. Ahead of upgrading our forecasts, the shares are trading on a FY2016F PER of 49.9x and an EV/EBITDA ratio of 38.7x. We reiterate our BUY stance on Fever-Tree.
